Title:
Mycelial carton galleries of Azteca brevis (Formicidae) as a
multispecies network
Journal: Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Abstract:
Apart from growing fungi for nutrition, as seen in the
NewWorld Attini, ants cultivate fungi for reinforcement of the walls of
their nests or tunnel-shaped runway galleries. These fungi are grown on
organic material such as bark, epiphylls or trichomes, and form stable
carton structures . In this study, the carton of the runway galleries
built by Azteca brevis (Formicidae, Dolichoderinae) on branches of
Tetrathylacium macrophyllum (Flacourtiaceae) is investigated. For the
first time, molecular tools are used to address the biodiversity and
phylogenetic affinities of fungi involved in tropical ant carton
architecture, a previously neglected ant fungus mutualism. The A. brevis
carton involves a complex association of several fungi. All the isolated
fungi were unequivocally placed within the Chaetothyriales by DNA
sequence data. Whereas five types of fungal hyphae were morphologically
distinguishable, our DNA data showed that more species are involved,
applying a phylogenetic species concept based on DNA phylogenies and
hyphal morphology. In contrast to the New World Attini with their
many-to-one (different ant species one fungal cultivar) pattern, and
temperate Lasius with a one-to-two (one ant species two mutualists) or
many-to-one (different ant species share the same mutualist) system, the
A. brevis fungi association is a one-to-many multi-species network.
Vertical fungus transmission has not yet been found, indicating that the
A. brevis fungi interaction is rather generalized.
